thread.title: Both unbeaten, Mervo and Patterson to meet in key city clash
thread.title_full: Both unbeaten, Mervo and Patterson to meet in key city clash

author: Katherine Dunn
title: Both unbeaten, Mervo and Patterson to meet in key city clash
text:
Both unbeaten, Mervo and Patterson to meet in key city clash 
Baltimore-area high school sports photos from the months of August and September 2015. Mervo has won 18 consecutive regular-season games, 17 against city opponents. 
Showdown between unbeatens Mervo and Patterson ranks among the biggest games in Baltimore City this season. 
No. 12 Mervo (5-0) at Patterson (5-0) 
When : Saturday, 1:45 p.m. 
Coaches : Patrick Nixon, Mervo; Larry Mitchell, Patterson 
Last meeting : Mervo won, 27-0, last season 
KEY PLAYERS TO WATCH 
Mervo : DE Malcolm Ali, Sr.; RB-DE Jowan Able, Sr.; WR-DB William Flowers III, Sr.; QB Garvin Nicholson, Sr.; DB-WR Nas Dockins, Sr.; C-DL Michael Covell Jr., Sr.; DT-FB Tajai Myles, Sr.; WR-DL Brandon Ben, Sr. 
Patterson : QB-LB Kennard Pugh, Sr.; RB-DB Raekwon Wright, Sr.; RB-DB Deandre McLean, Sr.; TE Damion Gaither, Sr.; RB-LB Dominic Watson, Sr.; OL-DL Amari Latimer, Sr.; OL-DL Damian Jackson, Jr.; OL-DL Deshawn Edwards, Jr. 
KEYS TO VICTORY 
This showdown between these Baltimore City rivals is not a league game, but it still ranks among the biggest games of the season. 
Mervo has won 18 straight regular-season games, including 17 against city opponents. Last season, the Mustangs finished the regular-season 9-0, second in Class 4A North before falling to Paint Branch, 42-8, in the regional semifinals. 
The Baltimore Sun takes Athletes of the Week nominations from Friday night until Sunday at 6 p.m. Please provide name, school, class, sport, position, team results and the athlete's accomplishments for the week, with statistics by game, and other supporting information. Coaches also should provide a number where they can be reached Sunday night. You can email your nominations to athleteoftheweek@baltimoresun.com . (Katherine Dunn, Glenn Graham) 
The Clippers reached the state Class 2A semifinals in 2013 and aim to rebound from a 6-4 finish last fall that kept them out of the playoffs. 
"Our experience has a whole lot to do with it," Mitchell said of this year's success. "We're not as talented as we have been in the past, but this team has experience and they know what they're doing. They've been through it so many times and they really understand the system." 
Patterson's biggest win came two weeks ago, 16-14, at Dunbar, a state Class 2A finalist last season. The Mustangs opened their season with a 12-10 win over South Hagerstown which looked more impressive two weeks later when the Rebels edged then-No. 5 South Carroll, 21-20. 
Both teams have solid quarterbacks with versatile offenses but the key to victory for both may lie in the defensive line. 
The Mustangs' line is built on defensive ends Ali and Dejuan Dallas and tackles Myles and Kevin Johnson . Ali has 19 sacks this season, including five in last week's 51-6 win over Northwestern. With those quick linemen and the linebackers, Mervo has done a good job stopping the run, Nixon said. 
The Clippers have a solid running game and they can also air it out. Pugh, who Nixon said is the best quarterback in the city league, has passed for 259 yards and four touchdowns and run for 100 yards. Wright has run 47 times for 359 yards and six touchdowns and caught five passes for 72 yards and two touchdowns. 
Patterson's defense uses a three-man front — Latimer, Jackson and Edwards — aiming to prevent the long ball, something Mitchell said will be key against the Mustangs. Pugh, who doubles as a linebacker, and Wright, a defensive back, can also wreak havoc on that side of the ball, combining for 25 tackles, three forced fumbles, two interceptions and a sack. 
Mervo's veteran quarterback Nicholson has thrown for 655 yards and 12 touchdowns while Ben has caught 17 passes for 312 yards and three touchdowns. 
The Mustangs' defense has allowed just 30 points and the Clippers have given up 38. 
"I think it's going to be almost like a boxing fight, 12 rounds and whoever's the last team standing is going to be the winner," Nixon said. "I think it's going to be a low-scoring, very physical game. You just can't blink. You can't hesitate. You can't stop battling until the end. And of course the turnovers and the mistakes — whoever makes the fewest, that's the team that's going to come out on top." 
OTHER GAMES TO WATCH 
No. 9 John Carroll at Boys' Latin, Friday, 3:45 p.m. 
No. 15 Arundel at No. 10 Broadneck, Friday, 6:30 p.m. 
No. 7 Archbishop Spalding at Calvert Hall, Friday, 7 p.m. 
Glenelg at Reservoir, Friday, 7 p.m.
